260.description:
As part of my PhD training, I designed university-level introductory courses (PS1200: Introduction to Comparative Politics) using an online learning management system (Carmen) to facilitate discussions and feedback. For several semesters, I have worked in tandem with Prof. Sarah Brooks to teach large-scale online courses, where my primary goal was to implement course objectives and maintain organization of course documents and assignments. As a graduate TA, I facilitate communication between students and Prof. Brooks, as well as between students themselves through online discussion forums. One method I use to incorporate current affairs and encourage communication is a weekly media discussion forum, wherein students update each other on happenings throughout the world. 

Prior to teaching online, I conceptualized, designed, and taught upper-level general education course on political extremism and right-wing movements in Europe (PS 4792.02: Topics in Contemporary Politics, Autumn 2014). For this course, I worked one-on-one with students and guided their research on self-selected topics relating to political extremism.

Also, in order to take advantage of the diversity in backgrounds and skill sets on our team, I worked with my team director to develop bi-weekly project focused round tables where team members could "shop" their projects, get feedback, brainstorm ideas, and trouble shoot problems.
260.title: Data Scientist (Contractor)

260.description: I work with authors, editors, and publishers to update and design supplementary material for comparative politics and international relations textbooks. This works requires not only that I stay up-to-date with current events, but also immersed in recent and upcoming academic works. I also design the course material so that it is easily adapted for both in-class and online courses.
260.title: Freelance Consultant

260.description: For my dissertation, I planned, managed, and implemented three year research project examining the psychological and political effects of hate crimes on immigrants in Germany. For this research, I raised $25,000 to conduct 10 months of hands-on research in Germany while contributing as a guest researcher at the German Institute for Economic Research and the Social Science Research Center in Berlin. While in Germany, I conducted face-to-face interviews and evaluated 30,000+ news articles to qualitatively explore the development of xenophobia and crimes since reunification (1990). Since data on hate crime distribution is unavailable in Germany, I organized and implemented collection of >10,000 parliamentary inquiries from 16 regional archives to produce unique data set on crimes against immigrants and minorities in Germany between 2006 and 2016 (to be released for public use in Spring 2017). Finally, to understand the psychological mechanisms underlying reaction to hate crimes, I designed and conducted survey experiment of immigrant and hard-to-reach populations in Germany to determine effects of short-term exposure to various levels and types of threats.
260.title: PhD Candidate

Normal Modes is a user experience consultancy that offers a range of services including usability testing, user experience (UX) design, and user research training. During my time at Normal Modes I specialized in usability testing and user experience research for large, data-driven websites and applications that required users to complete complex processes like those found in oil trading applications, booking engines, eCommerce systems, and specialized portals. 

While at Normal Modes, I was the senior researcher responsible for managing our entire research contract life-cycle. My responsibilities included meeting with potential clients, generating requirements documents, designing research plans that met client objectives, writing contract proposals, and the implementation and oversight of said research plans. Post data collection I was responsible for the synthesis, preparation, and presentation of complex research results to clients and other stakeholders in which I provided actionable and prioritized design recommendations based on the user performance data we collected. 

I was also responsible for our community outreach and business development efforts for which I taught complex regulatory concepts (e.g., the Food and Drug Administrationâs [FDA] human validation testing guidelines) and research methodology courses via webinars and other e-media (e.g., blogs).

As a member of these teams, I used my behavioral research expertise to help our investigators better understand the needs of patients and their medical providers. I also wrote and edited academic manuscripts, performed literature reviews using academic databases (e.g., PubMed, MEDLINE, EBSCOhost, and PsycInfo), and managed the activities of undergraduate medical students.

I also generally supported the research center by coordinating research activities, providing consultation on qualitative and quantitative research methodologies, and designing and structuring our data collection efforts including the data entry, maintenance, and query of large Microsoft Access databases.

310.description:
I worked as an educator at Tanglewood, an environmental learning center operated by the University of Maineâs Cooperative Extension. I developed and lead an environmental education curriculum for schoolchildren and school-groups.

Tanglewood provides affordable environmental education and nature-based experiences to Maine youth, to help them become effective and caring citizens of the earth. Tanglewood is surrounded by 840 acres of secluded forest, within the protected watershed of the Ducktrap river.

Tanglewood's Earth Connections program is a curriculum of experiential, immersive outdoor activities. It involves first of all stimulating an awareness, sensitivity, curiosity and wonder towards the beauty of the natural world -- to "tune into our senses and feelings, and to our inner voice, that connects us with everything in the universe", and then building off that foundation an understanding our natural habitat, in all its interconnected, interdependent complexity and diversity and beauty. So that ultimately we will have a better appreciation and respect for our responsibility to be caring inhabitants of it.

I developed, coordinated and lead an Earth Connections focus called âExploring the Secrets of the Ducktrapâ. We hiked through the woods and down the Ducktrap river to the estuary. We packed field guides, magnifying glasses and periscopes. We identified species and looked for patterns in nature. We played games and built models and read stories, to introduce important concepts about the natural world. We crafted miniature fairy houses and riverboats out of fallen birch bark.

I got to live in a simple cabin, and work and play outdoors in the woods, watching the leaves change colors and fall, and then  the river freeze over. Two years later I would move to California to begin my dream job as user experience researcher, working at Googleâs Headquarters in Silicon Valley.

337.description:
Envision a world where a population of networked programs and devices, each providing services and data, cooperate and compete to perform tasks for each other and for human users. Encouraging flexible cooperation in an environment where components offering new, perhaps unanticipated services can join in at any time. Computational elements would be able to express needs, tasks, and services at various levels of abstraction without hardcoding explicitly how the task should be accomplished or by whom. The decisions regarding which components will participate on a task are themselves arrived at in a cooperative, distributed fashion. This is the essence of delegated computing.

Areas of Exploration

In pursuit of this vision, our research interests have come to include (and combine):
Technologies for extended enterprise management (data visibility, comprehension, and rapid response)
Cloud Computing
Software Agents
Multimodal Interfaces
Artificial Intelligence
Machine Learning
Natural Language Processing
Natural Language Understanding
Spoken Language Dialog
Video and Image Analysis and Processing
Adaptive Interfaces (for varying classes of abilities and disabilities)
Collaborative (CSCW) Systems
Knowledge Management
Expert Systems
Ontologies
IoT/IIoT
Distributed Robotics
Autonomous Technologies

Through these responsibilities I was able to help complete a number of major projects that resulted in numerous journal and conference publications.

431.description:
As a Ph.D. student at Georgia Tech my responsibility was to lead interdisciplinary research teams, with collaborators from diverse backgrounds such as human-computer interaction, computer science, psychology, music, and industrial design. I helped assemble these teams, then guided them toward research goals, from research ideas and design through data analysis and dissemination. 

These teams performed a majority of their research within the area of applying multi-modal cues and novel interaction techniques to resource intensive multitasking situations.
Some of my research projects included:  
-The exploration of cognitive workload theory and detection
-The development and testing of a multi-modal eco-drive display to improve drivers fuel efficiency, without decreasing their situation awareness of the driving task
-The creation and testing of futuristic head up display interfaces for the vehicle and their interfacing with other modalities of information
-The creation and testing of methods of human input for future smart in-vehicle agents such as affect and cognitive workload
-The application of advanced auditory cues to decrease driving distraction while performing in-vehicle secondary tasks
-The design and testing of novel in-vehicle interaction techniques with multi-modal feedback such as gestures, touch-pads, and other interfaces
-Applying multi-modal cues to improve driving performance for special populations of drivers (e.g., individuals who have cognitive limitations, inexperienced drivers, aging drivers)

The research that my teams and I performed in these areas led to numerous journal publications and presentations at conferences such as Human Factors and Ergonomics Society Annual Meeting, Automotive User Interfaces and Interactive Vehicular Applications, and International Conference on Auditory Displays.

435.description:
As a UX Research Intern, I planned, implemented, and executed user research studies that would have a direct and significant impact on the design and function of one of Salesforce's products. During my internship I conducted two major research studies. The first was an exploratory research study collecting interview data that would be used to determine user needs and direct the future of the product. The second, most significant project was a full end-to-end summative benchmark usability study.

For the benchmark usability study, I created 15 tasks which tested the fundamental functions of the product, coordinated and communicated with product stakeholders and designers to validate the tasks, recruited participants, and conducted 90-minute (remote) sessions with 8 Salesforce customers. I then analyzed the 12+ hours of video data (using Morae usability software) under stringent time constraints, extracting usability metrics such as time-on-task, error rates, success rates, post-test perceived task ease/difficulty, and post-session System Usability Scale (SUS) survey data. I also collected qualitative data about points of confusion and delight with the product and suggestions for improvement and new features. The final product of this research study was a plethora of video data (8 participant videos broken into 15 task segments, accompanied by highlight and lowlight reels) and a final presentation of the usability findings (including participant video clips) which received high praise for being useful, pertinent, and easily understood.

437.description: I was the principal Investigator on four research studies investigating visual cognition, display clutter, and spatial ability. Through the course of my graduate career, I developed a new and unique research hypothesis investigating spatial processing and complex visual images. This novel method spawned a line of research in spatial abilities involving context and 6 different factors in visual complexity. I led 4 groups of 3-5 junior research assistants in formal research methodology and participant recruitment procedure. Scheduling and recruitment for over 300 face-to-face participants was coordinated over the course of several months.The data were analyzed using mixed ANOVA, ANCOVA, MANOVA, and multivariate regression. It was found that participants showed less difficulty in spatially processing objects when presented in a familiar environment.

439.description:
Fraunhofer CSE is part of the larger organization of Fraunhofer Geselleschaft, a German research institute which focuses on applied research and industry partnerships.
As a Research Fellow at Fraunhofer CSE, I worked on two contracts. The first contract involved quantifying human operator errors during power grid failures using cognitive task analysis and human reliability analysis (SPAR-H, CADET); this is a multi-year project undertaken in conjunction with the University of New Mexico. 
I also worked with the Solar Energy Group on a project focused on overcoming individual cognitive barriers to adopting innovative solar PV technology. This project entailed soliciting salient beliefs regarding solar PV from focus group participants, building an online experiment in Qualtrics, data collection and analysis and writing comprehensive reports. This is a multi-year contract research project in conjunction with the SunShot Initiative sponsored by the U.S. Department of Energy.
